Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Linking Pattern and Process in Cultural Evolution

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research seeks to contribute to understanding the origins of cultural diversity within and between human social groups. The researchers will develop an agent-based simulation model to capture demographic and cultural dynamics that affect the process of cultural evolution. The model will be used to perform an exploratory analysis of the varied and interacting effects of demographic and cultural factors on cultural diversity. The focus of the analysis will be on whether different pathways for the transmission of information between individuals (such as from parents to children or from peer to peer) result in different patterns of diversity.

The aim of the analysis is two-fold: first, to generate general theoretical insights about the roles of the different pathways of cultural transmission in shaping cultural diversity; second, to establish whether and under what conditions different pathways of transmission between individuals can be distinguished on the basis of data on the patterns of diversity across groups. The rationale is that if underlying processes cannot be accurately inferred from simulated data generated experimentally it is unlikely that they can be accurately inferred from empirical data.

Findings from the project will contribute to social science theory by addressing a fundamental theoretical question in the study of cultural evolution: the degree to which population-level patterns of cultural diversity can be reliably linked to individual-level processes of cultural transmission.The award is an Early-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) because the scale of the proposed modeling and analytical efforts are unprecedented in this area. One undergraduate student will assist with the analytical effort, thereby receiving training in the application of theoretical approaches to anthropological research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The study of cultural evolution is an emergent field in anthropology focused on understanding (i) the dynamics of cultural transmission of cultural traits (e.g., ideas, attitudes, beliefs) between individuals and groups, and (ii) the process of change in human culture over time. This project set out to develop a methodological and theoretical framework to investigate how individual-level interactions aggregate to produce population-level patterns of cultural diversity.

To achieve this aim, the project focused on three major components:

1.  development of an agent-based simulation model capturing the demographic and cultural factors involved in the process of cultural transmission and change. Demographic factors include group size and migration rate; cultural factors include the different “routes” for the transmission of cultural traits (outlined in 2. below) and the rate at which transmission events occur;

2.  analysis of the simulation results to produce general theoretical insights about the effects of the different transmission pathways and biases on cultural diversity. Possible pathways include (i) "vertical" transmission from parents to children, (ii) "horizontal" transmission between peers, and (iii) "oblique" transmission from older unrelated individuals to younger ones. The simulation model also included conformity bias, i.e., the tendency to acquire the most common variant in the population;

3.  analysis of the simulation results to gain insight into how cultural diversity is shaped by the different demographic and cultural factors (as outlined in 1. above). The specific research focus was to understand whether different transmission pathways leave characteristic signatures on the distributions of trait variants within and across groups. This addresses the key question of whether, and under what conditions, the different transmission routes can be distinguished on the basis of available data documenting variation in cultural traits within and across interacting human groups.

In addition to development of the simulation framework, the project involved investigating various statistical indices used to summarize the distributions of traits, and in particular to explore under what simulation scenarios the different transmission routes can be distinguished based on which indices.

We found that the different transmission pathways exhibit different dynamics, as expected, but they cannot be distinguished on the basis of population-level information at a single point in time, i.e. based on the frequencies of the different variants of a cultural trait present in the population. Rather, the pathways may be distinguished on the basis of information about how the frequencies of the different variants change over time. In particular, vertical and oblique transmission lead to relatively slow change in the cultural composition of a population, while horizontal and age-neutral (i.e., random) transmission result in faster change dynamics. These patterns are not substantially affected by frequency-dependent selection (through the inclusion of conformity bias).

Additional insight was gained through inclusion of phylogeny (i.e., the hierarchical pattern by which groups are related to one another, through descent from a common ancestor), as a proxy for population history. In particular, we found that transmission pathways different from vertical transmission do not “distort” the phylogenetic signal in synchronic population-level data. We also found that processes which lead to cultural homogeneity within groups (e.g., conformity bias) can effectively counteract the effects of horizontal transmission between groups.

Overall, these findings have substantial methodological implications for the study of cultural evolution, in particular with regards to widely-used cross-cultural databases...
